reviewText: As a fan of Kaufmann's other scripts, I saw this DVD in a bargain bin for 5 bucks, and figured I couldn't go wrong.  I read the back, and the premise sounded promising; a playwright builds a full scale New York City inside a warehouse and everyone involved in the play "loses themselves" in the process.  Sounded like good old Kaufmann-esque fun to me.It only took about forty minutes for me to realize this wasn't going to be any fun at all.  After 70 minutes, my circuitry overloaded.  My brain, fearing for my very sanity, made the executive decision to shut down.  I could analyze no more.When the movie ended, I felt confused, disappointed, irritated, and cheated.  When you invest two hours into a movie this willfully obtuse, you hope there's a pay-off at the end.  You hope the final scenes will be a revelation, that the "point" will finally be explained.  Synecdoche offers no such thing.Essentially a director tries to capture the "brutal truth" of life, becomes lost, and drags everyone down with him.  Maybe that's the point.  Life is too random and cruel to make any sense of.  Trying to adapt life into a play would result in a play every bit as random and senseless as life.But hey, what do I know?  This is a movie for people with much more patience and intellectual curiosity than I.  My fear is that even if a person "gets" this film, I doubt if they will get anything out of it.  It is a bleak, dark, humorless affair, and one gets the feeling the writer/director is daring his audience to enjoy themselves.

reviewText: ***The point/mood of the movie***The [intensely dark] mood and point of this movie I think is best summarized in a monologue given by a priest-actor at a funeral in the 107th minute:"Everything is more complicated than you think. You only see a tenth of what is true. There are a million little strings attached to every choice you make. You can destroy your life every time you choose. But maybe you won't know for 20 years, and you may never ever trace it to its source. And you only get one chance to play it out. Just try and figure out your own divorce. And they say there is no fate---but there *is.* It's what you create. And even though the world goes on for eons and eons, you are only here for a fraction of a fraction of a second. Most of your time is spent being dead or not yet born. But while alive, you wait in vain, wasting years, for a phone call or a letter or a look from someone or something to make it all right. And it never comes, or it seems to but it doesn't really. So you spend your time in vague regret or vaguer hope that something good will come along, something to make you feel connected, something to make you feel whole, something to make you feel loved. And the truth is, I feel so angry. And the truth is, I feel so f'ing sad. And the truth is, I felt so f'ing hurt for so f'ing long, and for just as long I've been pretending I'm okay, just to get along. Just for---I don't know why. Maybe because no one wants to hear about my misery, because they have their own. Well, f everybody. Amen."The real point of the movie, though, is what Sammy says minutes earlier: "I've watched you forever, Caden, but you've never really looked at anyone other than yourself."---***The point of the surrealism***This film, while ambitiously trying to capture all of reality in 120 minutes, injects a hefty dose of absurdity and surrealism. The point, I think, is actually to make it feel realer by suckerpunching you with some unconscious yet poignant images. David Foster Wallace said it best when describing David Lynch's Blue Velvet:"Blue Velvet captured something crucial about the way the U.S. present acted upon our nerve endings, something crucial that couldn't be analyzed or reduced to a system of codes or aesthetic principles or workshop techniques. The movie helped me realize that first-rate experimentalism is a way not to `transcend' or `rebel against' the truth but actually to *honor* it. It brought home that the very most important artistic communications take place at a level that not only isn't intellectual but isn't even fully conscious, that the unconscious's true medium isn't verbal but imagistic, and that whether the images are Realistic or Postmodern or Expressionistic or Surreal or what-the-hell-ever is less important than whether they feel true, whether they ring psychic cherries in the communicatee."---***The effect of the absurdity/surrealism***There were two scenes that especially rung my psychic cherries. One was in the 39th minute when Caden explains his theatre ambitions to Hazel as if to impress her, and yet she couldn't look more bored or uninterested. It was both hilarious and distressingly sad. Here's the quote:"The idea is to do a massive theatre piece--y'know, uncompromising, uh, honest. [Hazel's cheeks deflate, her eyes sag.] Here's what I think theatre is [Hazel looks down to find her tea, sips, raises her eyebrows in faux interest]: It's, um, the beginning of thought. It's, uh, the truth not yet spoken. [She looks back to the table, purses her lips in faux respect.] It's what a man feels like after he's been clocked in the jaw. It's love, in all its messiness. [She rests her head on her chin, then looks to see the source of the faint chatter behind her.] I want all of us, players and patrons alike, to soak in the communal bath of it. The mikfah, is what Jews call it. [Looks back again.] Because we're all in the same water, after all, soaking in our, uh, very... menstrual blood. And nocturnal emissions. This is what I want to try. [She finally shows genuine excitement because her soup has arrived!]"The other cherry-ringing scene, easily the saddest of the film, was in the 101st minute when Caden goes to find his grown daughter. He watches her tattooed naked body dispassionately dance and blow bubbles behind acrylic glass. She doesn't recognize him. She doesn't even notice him. "Olive, it's Daddy," he says as he knocks on the glass, growing increasingly more frustrated that she remains perfectly apathetic to his existence. He screams desperately, pounds the glass, and is escorted out. She keeps dispassionately dancing and blowing bubbles.----***In comparison to other similar-yet-not films***I've recently been on a kick of watching those films that Roger Ebert has declared the very best, the ones that seemingly try to and mostly succeed at capturing the enormity of life within their tiny bounds. It was really interesting to watch this film after watchingGates of Heaven(a documentary about a pet cemetery) andThe Tree Of Life(an even more ambitious film than this one) because the message, at core, is eerily similar if not exactly the same while the approach and mood is so dramatically different. If you were only going to watch one of those three, my strongest recommendation would be Gates of Heaven.

reviewText: This is a very complicated movie, with more than one theme.  But if I had to pick "the" primary theme, I would define it as the desire---for a great many people---to unnecessarily complicate their lives.When Philip Seymour Hoffman's character Caden returns home after having spent the day directing a local-community-theatre type production of DEATH OF A SALESMAN---a production in which he has deliberately chosen young actors to play the ordinarily middle-aged roles---he tells his wife that the show is scheduled to be performed with over 500 lighting cues before simultaneously asking her---in a rhetorical, disinterested manner---why he always has to make things so difficult."That's what you do," she replies just as casually.But then it isn't just Caden.  It's the way ALL of the people in the movie interact with each other.  The way the women in his life perceive his quirkiness in themselves, which is probably why they are drawn to him.  The way in which he falls so easily in, and then out of, love---abandoning that which is attainable in favor of something which is always over in the next, greener yard.  To casual movie goers, it will be easy to assume that Caden is a constant victim of circumstances, and that's a misconception.  Caden is an often selfish man who effects the lives of those around him, just as the selfish actions of others often affect him (he is seen to have a familiar pattern with Hazel: ignoring her when she herself is single, then finding himself attracted to her once she has found herself in a new relationship).The movie is about how we distract ourselves with what are often silly, meaningless goals---the more complicated (and "seemingly" noble) the better.  And how we are constantly seeking substitutes for the people who have hurt or left us, only to find ourselves in the same situations over and over again.

reviewText: It seems that there are only two opinions of this film.  It's either considered pure genius or pure garbage, with not room in between for balance.  So, why should I be any different; right?  I'm in the first tent, with all the other crazy people who happen to feel this movie is a work of raw genius.  Yes, there is so much purity, so much that is `real' here that it is impossible for me not to consider it a masterpiece.  I think that a film that begs you to question it is a film well work exploring, thus leading you to a deeper appreciation of what the director (or visionary as he or she should be called) intended you to feel.`Synecdoche, New York' is one of those films that needs to be experienced a few times before you can even begin to start answering the very questions it begs you to ask.The film tells a tale inside of a tale as we watch Caden Cotard attempt to bring meaning to his life by capturing the essence of life inside of his work.  A theater director who feels like his life is falling apart (which seems to be reflecting itself in the fact that his body is falling apart) decides, after his wife leaves him and he wins a grant, to construct the perfect theater piece; a piece that captures everything there is to feel and or know about life and death.  We are all aware that we will die, yet we are afraid to acknowledge that fact.  He rents out a huge (extremely huge) warehouse where he constructs a replica of New York City and hires actors to play actors to play actors, filling the space with tiny melodramas that capture life as it happens.All the while, his real life (which is merging gradually with his art) is in shambles.I'll scream SPOILER, just in case someone deems the next paragraph as so.There is a constant theme of death that runs throughout the film, but it is not to be taken as literal death, which I personally think is what makes this movie so phenomenal.  Caden's last name, Cotard, is a direct reference to `Cotard's Syndrome', which is the neuropsychiatric disorder where a person feels as though they are dead, that they do not exist or that they have lost all their blood or internal organs (yes, I got that from IMDB, thank you very much).  This is hinted a few times in the film (there is a reference made of Caden's daughter not having `blood' and a brief slip of the tongue where someone asks Caden why he committed suicide; thus insinuating that he is dead).  The thought that I gathered from this film is that when one does not know how to live they are in essence walking death.  They are not really living, and so they are not really alive.  Caden is a failure.  He hates his work because it is not `real' enough.  His family abandons him.  His body is falling apart (most likely a figurative sign that his life is falling apart) and so he is basically dead in a world that he doesn't understand.  What I found most fascinating is that it is not until he completely understands what it is that he has to do with his life that he is able to die, thus driving home the point that we are not necessarily supposed to live this life.Maybe this is just a rehearsal for something better to come later, after we are dead and gone.The acting here is phenomenal throughout, not a single sour note to be seen.  Kaufmann has a knack for writing scripts that lead way to great ensemble acting.  Look at what he did with `Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind', a film that not only carried strong lead performances but also flourished with a slew of supporting characters that all felt real and fulfilled.  Same can be said for `Being John Malkovich', which in my opinion soared with its supporting cast.  `Adaptation' was so well rounded throughout that no one single actor felt underused, even Maggie Gyllenhaal who had like two scenes.  `Synecdoche, New York' is no different.  Philip Seymour Hoffman was the perfect casting choice for Caden because he embodies this man's pathetic misery without losing that arrogance that makes his acting unique to himself.  He added color to Caden.  The supporting cast was exceptional, with Samantha Morton delivering one of the best supporting performances of the year, maybe even the decade.  Catherine Keener, Michelle Williams, Dianne Wiest, Emily Watson; the list goes on and on (and what an exceptional list).  Everyone does their share in creating characters that feel real and raw and pure, which can be hard when you are playing a person who is playing a person.Yes, `Synecdoche, New York' is ambitious and it is insane and it is maddening, but it pays off beautifully in the end, delivering one of the smartest and most enjoyably unique cinematic experiences in recent memory.  Don't avoid it because you don't think you'll get it.  Embrace it, fully immerse yourself in it, and I promise it will all make sense in the end.
summary: A world inside a world inside a richly fulfilled reality...

reviewText: While the concept of the film itself is not too hard to wrap ones head around, it is ultimately the existence of this film, as an actual film that got made and was just today released on Bluray no less that is completely insane because the film is so smart and dealing with topics rarely seen on the shelves of Target or Wall Mart.This film will confuse most people because it is a film about the very nature of existence and even more specifically the nature of existence as seen through the mind of a creative individual. To take the film literally is to do it an injustice. In fact people in general today, reviewers and moviegoers alike, tend to take films far, far to literally and often are unable to burry themselves into the art of a film. Many reviews I read of movies i enjoyed from trite garbage to better or great films tend to be written by people who only let the film skim off them like a skipping stone on a pond. All I can say to that is, "jump in people, head first!" We must all lose ourselves in art much more often and stop being so critical of everything. It is harder to take the time to appreciate films of all kinds than it is to see a film and be critical of it. Please do not decide right away if you loved it or hated it and rather let the film just stay with you for a while and mull it over. Everything out there from Dr Dolittle to the worlds most celebrated cinema has some merits. Please take the time to see what everything has to offer before summarily dismissing it. This film should not be written off too fast because you did not get it or it was too enigmatic, or too bizarre.My favorite films are ones that can be seen again and again and again and looked at from multiple ways of thinking and revisited from multiple points of view and times in ones life. This is one such film.Although this is sure to be a knee jerk simplistic view of the film I will say that the film itself is a metaphor representing each and every one of us. The main character, Caden, goes through many representations, male and female. Different people come in and out of his life. He is represented as seeing things from a variety of different perspectives and all the while his body is failing, as are all our bodies. We do what we can to stave off the inevitable but in the end death comes for us all. What we do here defines our lives. Wasting our time ultimately does no one an injustice but ourselves.The warehouse can easily be seen as a mind or the mind of Caden, and Caden himself as a representation of everyone. The dream like cuts and jumps in the film happen to us all daily as time slips away so very fast and accomplishments go unaccomplished and life is just lived. We wake from dreams all the time that are odder than the film itself. Our inner life of dreams and metaphor mirror our real lives in a way few ever understand.Fate and free will are tackled too in the movie. Do we have a choice to say what we say, do what we do, go where we go, or are we driven by unseen forces in the universe and beyond? Suspecting a bit of both and a tug of war is a decent conclusion to arrive at. This film seems to represent that tug of war we all have with what to do, where to go, what to say, and the forces that push and pull us as well from behind the curtains.Kaufman has explored this all before. Being John Malkovich with its puppets and people inside people controlling others from outside and from within. Our memories of people long gone still speak to us. Is it them, our memories of them, or do they live on inside us, controlling us?Much art, especially the cinema is viewed as pretend. This film takes that and suggests that perhaps it's not. A kiss is a kiss, no matter its intent. Is represented lovemaking the same as real lovemaking? Is the recorded reality of a film a reality nonetheless?This film may pose a lot of questions but it is something to be viewed and savored again and again. A film to be discussed. Something to cherish, rather than watched and thrown on the heap. Ultimately though, it is just another film, just as we are each just another life, no more or less special than everyone else around us.No go wrap your head around it. And for Gods sake, enjoy your life. Eventually it will end.
summary: Arguably the most profound film ever made.

reviewText: Synecdoche, New York is not for everyone. I liked it and I wanted to watch it a second time with a friend and five dogs. The dogs were a little bored, but willing to give it a chance, but my friend fell asleep, and then woke up only to complain constantly. "Is she going to be in the whole movie?" she asked about Olive (Sadie Goldstein), the 4-year old daughter of Caden Cotard (Philip Seymour Hoffman) and Adele Lack (Catherine Keener). Olive's persistent questions were annoying, but her anxiety was only a reflection of her parents' troubled relationship.When Caden Cotard was about to make love to his mistress, Hazel (Samantha Morton), my friend hit eject and refused to watch any more. Phillip Seymour Hoffman and William H. Macy are two men she would never want to see in flagrante delicto. Though I assured her that the scene was brief, and his attempt would prove futile, she refused to continue. We watched Hotel for Dogs instead, as it was something we all could enjoy; especially our five dogs, who never tire of whimsical canine antics.My friend has a Masters Degree and has read Marcel Proust's À la recherche du temps perdu in the French tongue, so I thought that she would appreciate an art house movie like Synecdoche, New York. Hazel is even shown reading Du cté de chez Swann or Swann's Way, the first book in Proust's multi-volume novel, while working in Caden Cotard's box office.Would my well read friend appreciate the allusion to Dr. Cottard, a recurring character throughout Proust's Remembrance of Things Past? No, she would not. Synecdoche, New York was just too bleak, dwelling on bodily malfunctions, dysfunctional relationships, and artistic failures and frustrations, for her to get past. Charlie Kaufman should have asked his twin brother, Donald Kaufman for a rewrite.Synecdoche, New York takes place in the suburb of Schenectady, New York, which has the distinction of having a zip code of 12345. Synecdoche (pronounced: si-nek-duh-kee (with a stress on "nek" (or in the case of the film, stress on the neck))) is a kind of metaphor where the part stands for the whole, as in "all hands on deck" where "hands," a part of a man, stand for the whole man.Besides the play on Schenectady, synecdoche pertains to this story because Caden Cotard, a play director, is given a MacArthur grant of $500,000 (granted, a Deus ex machina move, but without it there would be no story) to continue with his work. He mounts an enormous production in a huge warehouse, the set is almost as big as the City of Schenectady, New York, itself, therefore it is also a synecdoche, or a part of something that stands for the whole thing. All the people in his life are cast in this magnum opus, including him. Doppelgängers are everywhere. The parts stand for the larger whole.As Caden's production grows and grows, it contrasts with his wife's painting. Her paintings get smaller and smaller, until they can only be viewed with a magnifying glass. Nevertheless, in the art world, she is hugely popular. He is very frustrated with his own career, while his wife, Adele Lack, is on an upsurge. She takes Olive and moves to Berlin, leaving him to work on his major project, but somehow, he can never finish it, never perform it for an audience.Synecdoche, New York reminded me of Seinfeld, but without the laughs. Seinecdochefeld? Also set in New York, also a show about nothing, the episodes where Jerry and George pitched the idea for the fictional show-within-a-show that was picked up by the network, resulting in all of the Seinfeld characters having their own actor Doppelgängers, was a lot like Synecdoche, New York, only funnier. Tom Noonan, the guy who played Sammy Barnathan, the guy who played Caden Cotard in Cotard's play, even looks like Larry David, the guy who wrote Seinfeld with Jerry Seinfeld, and who stars as a fictional version of himself on Curb Your Enthusiasm. Larry David also recently starred in Woody Allen's Whatever Works, playing the part that Woody would've played himself.---------------Sammy Barnathan: I've watched you forever, Caden, but you've never really looked at anyone other than yourself. So watch me. Watch my heart break. Watch me jump. Watch me learn that after death there's nothing. There's no more watching. There's no more following. No love. Say goodbye to Hazel for me. And say it to yourself, too. None of us has much time.========================Bottom line is, Synecdoche, New York is not for everyone, but I liked it a lot. Still, like Caden's production, it builds and builds and you think there is going to be a major epiphany or revelation, but it never comes. There is a great eulogy given at a funeral for Sam Barnathan that kind of sums up the philosophy of Synecdoche, New York, but it's too little, too late. About 20 minutes before the end you are already asking, like Peggy Lee, "Is That All There Is?"--------------Caden Cotard: I know how to do it now. There are nearly thirteen million people in the world. None of those people is an extra. They're all the leads of their own stories. reviewText: I'm not sure how I feel about this movie.  I couldn't tell you if it was entertaining or enjoyable. I can't deconstruct its plot, criticize its direction, or judge its approach. It's hard for me to even articulate my reaction to the film, let alone critique it.So why are there 5 stars attached to this review?If nothing else, I strongly feel that this movie is singular, unique, unlike anything that has been made, and something that can never be remade. In turn, the experience of watching this film is singular, unique, unlike anything that may have been experienced before, and something that can never be replicated. This film could've only been made by this writer/director, at this time in his career, and at this stage in his artistic pursuits.  It is wholly his vision; pure, unadulterated, and put to film. Isn't that what true art really is?I feel that the witnessing true art occurs when you experience another's creation that you know is above you. In other words, you know you couldn't have possibly created yourself, and that it probably couldn't have been created by anyone other than the creator himself. It's the experience of seeing something that you can't quite fully wrap your head around... when you can't quite conceive of the thought processes of the person who brought it into existence. So you simply watch, almost in a state of awe, and experience the film exactly how it is, and how it was meant to be.Maybe with future viewings I can sort out the minor details... like if I was "entertained" or if this movie was well made, paced, and constructed by the standards of modern cinema. But these details ultimately don't matter. All that matters is that this film provided me a unique viewing experience... one that I have never quite experienced before and one that I don't think I'll ever quite experience again. And it's something I wouldn't trade and certainly won't soon forget.

Life has the same conditions for all of us; it's simply the time inbetween us not yet being born and us being dead. reviewText: I love it when pretentious movie reviewers attempt to demonstrate their intellectual credentials by stating, "If you don't like movies without good guys, bad guys and explosions, this isn't for you."  Guess what?  There are plenty of good movies with explosions and plenty of good movies without good guys or bad guys.  Synecdoche has neither but that isn't why it is a terrible film.  It is a terrible film because it is a depressing, self-indulgent series of uninvolving scenes strung together with unlikable characters.At its heart, Synecdoche is about a playwright who, having found success in small plays, receives a grant of apparently endless proportions and decides to create a full-sized `living' play that explores the woe and despair of human life and how it all ends in death.  With this whole "art is life" in place, the audience is mirthlessly treated to two hours of watching characters pretending to be miserable and suffering or actually being miserable and suffering in their real lives.  Maybe.  The way  Kaufman stages everything, it is impossible to tell which is which and even when he does, he is just as apt to make it neither by throwing in arbitrary weirdness.  Wow, the woman lives in a burning house?  Is it real?  Is it part of the play?  Does it matter?  No.The problem is that when it's all said and done, who cares?  There isn't a single character you can invest in because they lack any engaging qualities, aren't given anything notable to do, or are relegated to walk-on roles that we are just `supposed' to value because they are crying and being dramatic and, you know, full of artsy angst.  There are some fantastic actors in here and you can see them desperately trying to make something out of the disjointed scenes they are given to work with but in the end their labors are for nothing.  By the haphazard nature of the film, it doesn't matter how much heart and soul the actors put into their performances because two scenes later they will dead, played by another actor, or have their performance re-written as a dream/hallucination/misinterpretation.  As an example, early on in the film a character suffers from a bucket-load of diseases that may be terminal, by the middle of the film he's A-ok and it is never addressed, so what was the point?  Oh that's right, human life is all about diseases and dying and despair...Which brings me to my final beef with this film:  its unapologetically bleak view of the human condition.  Seriously, there is not a laugh to be found in this sob-fest and when a character chuckles you better believe they are doing it to keep from crying.  A telling scene shows the playwright writing his daily notes for all of his actors - a huge table filled with hundreds of notes - and they are all entirely negative.  "You were just raped", "you lost your job", "your daughter died", "you wasted two hours of your life watching Synecdoche".  This is 100% Emo despair, a love-letter to everything that is awful about life and where the only good thing that happens to people is dying.  Boo-hoo.Seriously, the people who think this movie reveals some sort of deep insight into the breadth and scope a human existence really are missing out on something.  I can only hope that if they make the mistake of sitting through Synecdoche that they won't give up entirely.P.S.  I think what is going on here with the "Best Film of Year" reviews is that people can't separate their love for the artist from this film.  I think that Kaufman could poop in a toilet and his adoring fans would line up and pontificate and giggle at how his defecation was the very height of insightful `cleverness'.  I wonder how many of them even understood the fact that, essentially, this is exactly what Kaufman did: there are at least three shots of a turd in a toilet bowl and at least two shots of character wiping themselves.  I can't imagine that he would intentionally do this towards his fans (who else would defend him?) but I also wouldn't put it past his self-absorbed ego to think he could make people think it meant something.
summary: A self-Indulgent, despairing film with no hope in sight

reviewText: The question for this complex and weird film is whether writer-director Charlie Kaufman's artistic ambition will ultimately frustrate viewer patience. When I saw the film, a couple in front of me walked out halfway through. You will probably love or hate this film; reviews have been sharply divided.Philip Seymour Hofmann stars as Caden Cotard, a theater director mired in all the midlife crises, real and imagined, of body, mind and spirit. The film begins conventionally enough, or so it seems, but there are telltale signs early-on that Kaufman is going to play with reality itself -- a cartoon on the family TV features Caden as a character, and a realtor walks a client through a house that is permanemtly on fire. Those are two ominous metaphors.The giveway is that the name "Cotard" bears a striking resemblance to that of the French postmodernist Jean-Francois Lyotard. We shouldn't be surprised when Caden quits his career doing theater among the "blue hairs" in suburban Schenectady, New York, where his latest production was "Death of a Salesman," and with the help of a MacArthur genius grant (a cruel irony given his circumstances) moves to a cavernous warehouse in New York City and recreates his confused life through what eventually becomes a cast of hundreds of characters. Yes, life is a stage and we're the actors.In his book The Post-Modern Condition (1979), Lyotard made (in)famous the notion of "incredulity toward meta-narrrative," a fancy way of saying that there are no truly universal or absolute meanings or truths in life, and that all meaning is a personal or social construction. This is exactly what Caden tries to do -- he creates meaning in his life through characters who portray his life. He keeps changing the name of the play, one of which is "Simulacrum" (= an insubstantial semblance of something). He keeps saying that he "finally" knows how he wants to direct the play. Indeed, the play is never finished but is instead a building project that piles floor upon floor of sets; it never ends. For Kaufman there's a very thin line between authenticity and absurdity, genuine reality and mere representation, living life and playing roles, healthy self-awareness (however painful) and oppressive self-consciousness, and between true life and certain death.Does Caden's effort to manufacture even the barest micro-meaning make any sense? The last line of the movie offers a glimmer of hope. Maybe.

The production gets bigger and bigger to the point where they need to hire an actor to portray the actor who is portraying Caden.The movie can be a big confusing at times, with an occasionally deceiving passage of time and recursive references. It's rather similar to the classic quote from Shakespeare, "All the world's a stage, and all the men and women merely players." It's Kaufman's presentation which breathes new life into the old idea and makes for an interesting movie which is well worth watching.

reviewText: "Synechdoche" is a long (2-hour) puzzle-box of a movie, often self-referential to the point of annoyance. It starts off with a lengthy depiction of the Job-like tribulations of the central character, Caden Cotard, and then moves into the main story. It is no accident that the play Cotard is directing as the movie opens is "DEATH of a Salesman," and there are endless references to death throughout the movie. I would have given this 4 stars if the first 1/3 of the movie had been edited to half its actual length.
summary: A long meditation on life and death. Mostly death.

reviewText: One of the great anxieties of our time is that we no longer live in a world with fixed categories. Everything, we learn, is constructed, and provisional, and in the process of becoming something else. Even us, especially us. As Jean-Francois Lyotard reminds us "constant change has become a status quo" and as Vaclav Havel reminds us "we live in the postmodern world where everything is possible and almost nothing is certain". Some postmodern artists accept and even celebrate the new status quo and construct fictional games that find comedy in the eternal play between an unfixed and unknowable self and an unfixed and unknowable world. Others, like Charlie Kaufman, are pretty stressed about this status quo and want to find some authentic self to cling to even if they know or at least suspect that no such thing as an "authentic self" exists.Another source of anxiety for the postmodern artist is that in the postmodern age nothing is altogether original. Everything reminds us of something else. Charlie Kaufman is not the first artist to attempt to cram the entirety of his existence nor the entirety of one of his myriad-minded and ever-changing character's existence into a single work of art (think Laurence Sterne, James Joyce, and Thomas Pynchon) and he's not the first to find that "the self", in all its variety and abundance, does not really fit into a single work of art (think Robert Musil whose Man Without Qualities, brilliant though it may be in parts, only ends when its author dies, literally). He's also not the first movie director to make a movie about a movie director making a movie...Postmodern reflexivity came of age in the cinema in the sixties when Fellini and Truffaut did it in 8 1/2 and Day for Night respectively. Charlie, however, has the enormous disadvantage of not only following two acknowledged masters of the medium into this subgenre but he also has the disadvantage of already having done the self-reflexive thing in BOTH of his previous two feature films. Say what you will about the flexibility of the postmodern subject, Charlie Kaufman seems pretty attached to his signature conceit.Though the point may be that there is no way of ending this kind of film, there is an undeniable pathos in this film for as Charlie Kaufman aka Caden Cotard attempts to assemble the fragments that he knows will never cohere into a single unifying "Charlie Kaufman aka Caden Cotard"-whole, his real life falls to pieces. If he had a choice and he could choose between "art" and "life" then we might lose sympathy but as he brings the thing (his art? his life? in the postmodern there is no clear boundary separating these two) to life one piece at a time each piece takes on a life of its own until it is bigger than he is. Ultimately, he is simply a piece in a self-generating puzzle over which he has no creative control and over which he can claim no authorship (or auteur-ship).How enjoyable is this kind of thing? Mildly entertaining. A select audience (those who adore Charlie Kaufman and those who adore Philip Seymour Hoffman) will adore this film but most, I am guessing, will find this film a bit too gimmicky and a bit too geeky.

reviewText: i thought this film was beautifully ambitious and challenging, and my wife thought it was "icky people, icky places, worst film i've ever seen". that pretty much covers the spread in the ratings here.about halfway through the film i burst out laughing. not at any particularly humorous turn (the film is full of humor), but because i had been hanging onto the film the way a dangling man hangs by his fingertips from a high ledge, and finally i just had to let go. my interpretation of what was going on collapsed. my belief that i was making sense of it all evaporated. i had to laugh.in retrospect, the words spoken by the priest near the end of the film tugged me back in. we pass through life playing roles, and pretending other people are playing roles, and thereby distance ourselves from life itself. synecdoche is the rhetorical device of using the part to stand for the whole (asking for a woman's "hand" in marriage), and kaufman presents a feckless stage director who orchestrates dramatic parts (the pun must be intentional) to stand for whole people, a director whose vast dramatic project is the vast inner theater of roles and the uncertain manipulation of action that form his connection to the real world. "when are we going to have an audience?" one of the dozens of actors demands of him. never -- because the director is the audience, and the impatient actor is just the image of some real person in the director's solitary mind.i can't claim to understand why every real person except his ex wife and their daughter is played by an actor (they become idealizations rather than real people?), or why the ex wife's paintings must be examined with magnifying glasses, or why the director's mistress reads proust and lives in a house that is continually afire, or why she turns flirtatious with the actor playing the director, or why that actor commits suicide and the director decides to take the part of a cleaning woman so that the actress playing the cleaning woman can replace the actor playing him as the director ... it becomes a hall of mirrors and puzzles, and meanwhile the dramatic project grows into the size of a city ... why? why? perhaps because our answers to the questions of life make a city of fiction, and we consume our life directing the actors we use to populate it.despite my wife's reaction, i believe the ambition, visual language, and life history arc of the narrative, the symbolism and interpretive traps, the quality of the acting (especially by philip seymour hoffman, christine keeler and samantha morton) and the sheer hilarity of the many dramatic metaphors, will commend this film to your attention ... at least once. i can't predict if you will laugh or snarl when the film finally escapes your understanding, but i hope it does, because the film seems to me to suggest that any interpretable theater of identity only walls us off from our brief and uniquely incomprehensible existence.

reviewText: "Synecdoche, New York" represents a world that lies somewhere between fantasy and reality. An ailing director, Caden Cotard (Philip Seymour Hoffman) builds a replica of New York in a huge cavernous warehouse and instructs his actors live out constructed lives. He hires an actor to play himself, and others to play the people he knows. The staging of the play takes on a life of its own as the sets just keep getting bigger and bigger and more elaborate, until the fabricated New York begins to look every bit as real as a real city. And when the actors begin to intermingle with Cotard's real life the line between the play and real life becomes even more blurred. The movie starts off as something of a black comedy where everything that can go wrong starts to go wrong for Hoffman's character, but then about half way through the movie the movie seems less black comedy and more just interesting, like a Jean Luc Godard film might, and we watch as his obsession with this theatrical production, that never has an audience except for the actors themselves, takes on a life of its own, and goes on year after year. But the movie does have a somewhat positive side to it in that despite everything Caden perseveres right to the end even though ironically one of the actors playing him can't take it anymore and dives off a building in despair. This is a fascinating movie that will frustrate some and stimulate others. Just sit back and enjoy this labyrinth from the mind of Charlie Kaufman ("Adaptation", "Being John Malkovich").

reviewText: Saying this film is not for everyone is probably the understatement of the year. After watching every depressing minute of it (and not comprehending any of them) I think that there is a good chance this film might not be for anyone. But in spite of the fact that it was self-indulgent, rambling, and very, very long, I felt compelled to give it five stars--because Kaufman truly is a genius.Now I have to explain myself. The reason I thought this was a great, if not particularly likable film, was that in Synecdoche, Kaufman bit off more than he could chew (always a noble endeavor) and then proceeded to chew it, jaw unhinged. What Kaufman was tackling in this movie (besides his own depression) was not mid-life crisis. It was the ultimate meaningless of life itself and a single person's unwillingness to succumb to that idea -- in spite of its undeniable truth. Throughout the movie, the main character, Caden, doggedly tries to make sense of his life by projecting it into a play. This was not simply a case of egoistic self-indulgence (we watch Woody Allen films for that). It was a quest for truth itself. (A phrase Caden himself repeats endlessly.) The irony is that the macrocosm that Caden seeks to represent (i.e. life) through one of its parts (New York), cannot be represented. How can one grasp one's own existence? Even if you look into a mirror, what you see is not you. And this sums up both the futility and the allure of Caden's grand project.For many, a film which is so blatantly, and so morosely, existentialist will hold no appeal. However, unlike the all-too-serious French, Kaufman can't help poking fun at his own sense of futility, resulting in some truly funny moments. The constant search for finding someone to "play" himself, ends up with a cleaning lady who eloquently and succinctly sums up Caden's "character" while holding a mop. The apartment which is constantly on fire, the suicide of one of Caden's actors ("Get up! I didn't jump!"), the daughter who is killed by her tattoos, all add an element of pointed absurdity that saves the film from wallowing in its own ennui.The other saving grace of this film was Philip Seymour Hoffman, who played his part so brilliantly, and so convincingly, that I sat at the edge of my seat for the entire film. (All the while confusedly whispering to myself, "What's going ON?")When all is said and done, Hoffman was the reason this film worked. Without the degree of sympathy he was able to elicit, nobody could have sat through it.The final justification that I will offer for giving this incomprehensible film five stars, is that Kaufman was successful in his quest to completely blur the lines of reality. Very few film writers are capable of creating a reality that we fully recognize as being ours, and then slowly blurring its edges to the point where that reality is completely erased. Yet we still believe in it, even past the point where we cease to recognize what "it" is. Kaufman does not create fantasies, but something darker, something that leaves us uncomfortable, something that hints at a bottom line we'd rather not face. Whatever that dark something is, I must acknowledge that only Kaufman can pull off making it so thoroughly credible, and with so little regard to whether or not the end product is marketable. For that reason alone this film was an achievement, and well worthy of its stars.*Footnote: Since so many people appear to have missed the significance of the title, "synecdoche" is a term of Greek origin meaning "the whole is represented by the part." For example, many curse words use parts of the human anatomy to describe the entire person. As a further ironic touch, Caden's perpetual search for a title which will sum up the meaning of his play/life is provided by the title of Kaufman's movie. The locale, Schenectady, was chosen as a play on words--among other things. (It is also an instance of synecdoche.) Once the meaning of the title becomes clear, the puzzle is: Which part represents which whole? If you can answer the question, you will have solved the puzzle of Synecdoche: New York.
summary: Kaufman's biggest jigsaw puzzle ...with a hidden piece

reviewText: Charlie Kaufman is my hero. He has been without a doubt one of the best modern writers since the film Being John Malkovich. Now, after his directing debut Synecdoche, New York (2008) which he made based on his own script, I believe that Kaufman has taken the  unique position among the best, most creative, ambitious, visually interesting directors of our times. Synecdoche, New York is a fascinating film, deep and profound, dramatic and funny, sophisticated and innovative, complex yet clear.  Kaufman was able to gather a dream cast of extremely talented intelligent actors and each of them gave a performance they should be proud of. As a matter of fact I did not expect anything less from the man behind Being John Malkovich and Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004). Before I watched the film I knew I would be confused, lost, maybe even infuriated sometimes but it is great to get lost in such incredibly complicated but outstanding work of Art with a capital A. Yes, of course Synecdoche, New York brings to mind the great movies of the past. Woody Allen's Crimes and Misdemeanors, Stardust Memory or Deconstructing Harry, which in turn reminds so much of Ingmar Bergman's Wild Strawberries were the first I remember. I also think of Synecdoche as Fellini's 8 1/2 sans Nino Rota's music. So what? All artists come to the point when they have to explore the old but forever burning themes of the human existence on their own. What is life? What is its meaning? How unique every life is? How each of us, every single one is a main hero of our own story and how unique every story is? What is the purpose of Art? Why and how love dies? Is it possible to survive and forget it? reviewText: SYNECDOCHE, NEW YORK is a firecracker display that sets the audience up for a grand epic of adventures then sputters its lovable way through over two hours of loosely connected views of life as we live it - through the eyes of an increasingly physically disabled director Caden Cotard (Philip Seymour Hoffman).  Trying to summarize what the story is and does is always as risky task when it comes to Charlie Kaufman films and the audience for this work will be decidedly separated between the love it or hate it division.Kaufman manages to address so many issues (marriage, adultery, joblessness, that thin thread of sanity that keeps actors committed to impossibly complex problematic productions, etc) that keeping up with the nonlinear story line is challenging at best.  But with a cast of characters as finely portrayed by actors such as Samantha Morton, Catherine Keener, Hope Davis, Michelle Williams, Jennifer Jason Leigh et al, the whole crazy film works wonders on the imagination.  This is pure entertainment for the sake of entertainment and while Caden Cotard does represent Everyman searching for some semblance of meaning in a universe that makes little sense (except that death is inevitable!), it is the process more than the dialogue that makes this film such a pleasure to follow.  Charlie Kaufman has done it again....Grady Harp, March 09

reviewText: Synecdoche-Noun-A figure of speech in which a part is used for the whole or the whole for a part, the special for the general or the general for the special...Synecdoche, New York is the directorial debut of Academy Award-winning screenwriter Charlie Kaufman (Best Original Screenplay,Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (Widescreen Edition)), who has written some of the most acclaimed films of the last several years. Like his previous screenwriting efforts, Synecdoche, New York is a complicated, thought-provoking film that floored many critics, yet somehow, almost blasphemously, escaped Academy attention.Describing the plot of this film isn't done very easily, but it's something like this:Oscar-winner Philip Seymour Hoffman (Best Actor,Capote) plays Caden Cotard, a theater director married to an artist named Adele (Catherine Keener), with whom he shares a daughter named Olive. When Adele goes to Berlin for an art show, she tells Caden that she only wants Olive to go with her...She doesn't come back. Caden is lonely, unfulfilled, sick, and without any joy in his life. He confides to a therapist (Hope Davis), "I'm afraid I'm gonna die. I don't know what's wrong with me and I want to do something important while I'm still here." Caden is award a MacArthur grant, which gives him unlimited money to pursue artistic endeavors. This leads him to stage a massive theatre piece in New York, amidst his flirtatious relationship with Hazel (Oscar-nominee Samantha Morton) who lives in a house that's literally on fire...And getting re-married to Claire (Oscar-nominee Michelle Williams).The film has a ridiculous amount of familiar actors in it, but a couple more include Tom Noonan as a mysterious man who is seen lurking in the background of several scenes before winning the part of Caden in Caden's play. Also, there's Emma Watson as Tammy, who plays Hazel on stage. Academy Award-winner Dianne Wiest, who was everywhere during the 80s and 90s, also appears...This took me away from the spell of the movie had cast on me for a moment to think "Holy s***, is that Diane Wiest?"Based on Kaufman's eccentric personality it wouldn't be unreasonable to think Caden is based on Kaufman to some extent.The story does have Kaufman's stamp on it. Like his previous efforts it is very intricate, confusing at times, and very aware of human conditions. It's probably unjust for me to write about this film until I've seen it more than once. Kaufman has said this film exists in a sort of dream reality and it does have a dreamy feel to it and what occurs in the film isn't very linear. It's the closest thing to I've seen to seeing a dream being filmed. The way the film flows from one scene to another is just like a dream, with not everything making sense immediately, people coming and going, etc.It's a very complicated film and it's quite impressive that Kaufman chose to direct this film having never directed one before. It was a good choice though, as there are many scenes that would be laughable in the wrong hands. Kaufman keeps everything poignant and deeply affecting.The performances are amazing. Hoffman is absolutely brilliant. The nuance he brings to this multi-faceted character is no small feat. Tom Noonan comes out of left-field as Sammy, the creepy actor who follows Caden for 20 years before playing him. In a film that's full of great performances, this is surprisingly one of the best.As it is a film with themes of age, life, death, relationships, time, and identity it was compared to the incredibly overratedThe Curious Case of Benjamin Button. This film does have similarities to that film in the themes they share; the difference is that film was made on a bigger budget, with a script that was self-plagiarism on Eric Roth's part (anyone who paid attention while watching it will say it was "Forrest Gump 2"), but looked pretty and had great performances. Synecdoche, New York has a smaller budget, a terrific script, great performances, and it looks pretty. Beyond that, it explores the same themes as the previous film and is much more successful. This film is much more profound than that film and most of the films that were released in 2008...This film is a fascinating and profound experience, although not a film for the impatient. Synecdoche, New York does something few films can do. It gets you on an emotional level; it plays your emotions like an instrument, making you laugh and breaking your heart at its will. It's really something special and truly one of the best films of 2008. It deserves to be seen, discussed, and seen again. Try not to sit in awe of what you've seen once it's over.GRADE: A

reviewText: Synecdoche, New York is a 2008 movie that takes place primarily in Schenectady, New York.  It is outstanding screenwriter Charlie Kaufman's directorial debut and of course he pens the screenplay here just as he did for immaculate and intricately written filmsAdaptation,Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind, andBeing John Malkovich.  Given my leaning more so in an education of the social sciences I viewed the film as though it were the delusions of a narcissistic hypochondriac reaching to find happiness and love somewhere within his own preoccupation with failure, illness, and dying.  I've heard others say the film is taking place in dreams and so forth, and while other perspectives probably have merit it doesn't really matter as the film asks us to ponder on more meaningful points instead.  Fair warning though, it is a not a palpable film for everyone and many will either not be provoked enough to bother understanding it or they will miss the point and write it off as pretentious.  It is not pretentious and I say it's among the most well-written films in a number of years.It follows Caden Cotard (Phillip Seymour Hoffman), a theater director and artist struggling through his increasingly emotionally challenging life.  After his wife and child leave for Germany he suddenly receives a MacArthur Fellowship award and begins to work on a life size version of the real city outside.  His project gradually becomes more and more of an imitation of the outside world, his interpersonal relationships wax and wane, his body is slowly shutting down, and his cast begins making some very strange and unlikely changes.  All the world's a stage indeed, until of course you kill yourself off.This is a terrific film that unfortunately received a limited release in the United States and in the long run fell far short of breaking even with his budget.  It features a cast of amazing actors such as Tom Noonan, Catherine Keener, Samantha Morton, Hope Davis, and Jennifer Jason Leigh among others.  Of course Phillip Seymour Hoffman brings a great performance to the table as he is truly one of the best actors of our generation.  This cast accompanied with a tight and complete vision for Kauffman makes for a challenging but extremely rewarding package.  Fredrick Elmes does the cinematography here so it's no wonder I was preparing to say something about how Kauffman's directorial style channels David Lynch.  It actually channels Elmes very distinct style because he worked on the film.  It's a shame that this kind of movie with this kind of budget will probably become less commonly exposed to the mainstream with time simply because greedy distributors do not want to take the risk.  Movies that dare to search for meaning in this life simply need to be made, seen, and understood.
summary: It's a Big Decision, How One Prefers to Die

reviewText: Synecdoche, New York stars Philip Seymour Hoffman as a theatrical director desperately searching for the meaning of his life, truth and happiness itself. The acting is superb; you couldn't ask for more convincing acting. The cinematography and the choreography display great attention to detail and intense planning. If the film does suffer somewhat, it suffers from the plot being too complicated. Kaufman wanted this film to tackle many types of relationships and it juggles reality and fantasy pretty much throughout the film. In one particularly surrealistic scene that highlights the extent to which Charlie Kaufman is willing to go to inject fantasy into this film, we see someone brought by a realtor to see a house for sale--yet the house is perpetually on fire without anyone ever calling the fire department! The house perpetually burns--what an image! Overall, however, it's a fascinating motion picture and Charlie Kaufman is off to a strong start as a director.When the film starts we meet Caden Cotard (Philip Seymour Hoffman), his wife Adele Lack (Catherine Keener) and their four year old daughter Olive (Sadie Goldstein). The Cotards have clearly fallen out of love and ultimately Adele surprises Caden by announcing that she wants to go to an art show in Berlin with just Olive and not with both Olive and Caden as they had planned. Caden is devastated and he waits over a year, still wearing his wedding ring, hoping that Adele will return to him. Adele, however, has apparently found great fame and fortune in Berlin with her picture displayed on the covers of magazines; and Caden is horrified to see in a photo that his very young daughter has been tattooed all over! To make matters worse, Caden is very much a hypochondriac who is constantly thinks he's dying all the while actually suffering from some sort of very slowly disabling disorder that won't end his life anytime soon. Even Caden's therapist is rather unusual; she pushes her own books and throws herself at Caden but he only buys one book from her.As time passes Caden has an affair with a young box office girl named Hazel (Samantha Morton); but then Caden chooses marriage with actress Claire Keen (Michelle Williams) instead. Caden meets Claire when he is doing the initial casting for a show about his life; and this show is to be staged using a vacant warehouse as a theater. It's amazing how complicated Caden's play becomes as he delves ever deeper in his quest to find truth and meaning in his life which he rightly feels is sad and heartbreaking. There are eventually hundreds of performers!Of course, from here the plot can go anywhere; and although I've written a lot there's plenty of good material I omitted so that this film can hold your attention. What happens if Caden ever wants to see his daughter Olive again--will they reunite? Under what circumstances could they ever reunite? What about Adele and Claire--will they stay in Caden's life or will they come and go as the years go by? Does Caden's play, sponsored by a grant, ever get produced? Watch the movie and find out!The DVD comes with several extras. I liked the featurette that has Philip Seymour Hoffman talking about Caden's character; and "In And Around Synecdoche, New York" is very well done with some comments by cast members and Charlie Kaufman. There is another interesting discussion of the film in the extra entitled "Infectious Diseases In Cattle: Bloggers' Round Table." The "NFTS/Script Factory Masterclass" forum and interview with Charlie Kaufman is very good as well.Unfortunately, I can't give this film a five star review. Kaufman packed too much into a two hour movie that covers nearly fifty years of life. The plot is extremely complicated. I also didn't like that there are several very quick fast forwards in time that imply that nothing of any significance happened during seven or eight years at a time; that disappoints me. On the other hand, the film still retains a very real artistic quality. The film showcases the human struggle to understand the meaning of life and the desire to make a lasting impression upon others (in this film, Caden's play) that will exist long after one is deceased. I definitely recommend this film for people who like films that mix fantasy and reality; people who enjoy films similar to  "Being John Malkovich," "Adaptation" and "Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind" will probably love "Synecdoche, New York." reviewText: The Film:Kaufman is known for his "meta" style, and the fact that his scripts often take place in a head space very different from most films. Well, these qualities are ratcheted up to the Nth degree in "Synecdoche," and the result is both one of the most challenging as well as (perhaps) one of the most profound films committed to celluloid in the past 100 years or so of the medium.In a sentence, the story might be summarized as "A stage director in Schenectady, New York suffers through a failing marriage, an inability to maintain meaningful relationships after that failure, and an overwhelming desire to create a meaningful, enduring work of art." This could probably be a pretty good movie. But I don't think it is this movie. My interpretation (and take it for what it's worth) is that this movie is the story of a man looking back at the life summarized above from its ending, and feeling a sadness in both the fact that life is ending and in the fact that he did not live it to its fullest. This sadness is underscored by the realization that the act of relentlessly analyzing the past, as he is doing upon his death, was what prevented him from living fully in the first place.Annnnyway... as a film, it is mesmerizing. Kaufman proves himself as able a director as a screenwriter, in being able to create a universe which feels real (despite its dreamy logic) and feels compelling. Small details litter the landscapes, especially details that indicate which layer of the protagonist's recollection we are seeing. Music and ambient noises are also integrated in a very surrealistic and atmospheric way. The performances, especially P.S. Hoffman's, are tremendously good - well studied, naturalistic, and convincing. Make-up also plays a significant role in this production, as it covers 40 years of recollection and aging.This is not a film everyone will love. Even those who consider themselves aficionados of Kaufman's other films may find it too obscure to be enjoyable. So let me say, in bold letters: RENT THIS BEFORE YOU BUY IT. At least watch it at a friend's house or something. Read some reviews first. Really research it. This film may not be for you, and if so you will rue the day you dropped $20-plus on it. But if you love it, if you "get it" (if indeed it is possible to "get"), this is a film that will grow and change in your understanding with repeated viewings. This is a characteristic of all great literature and film. "Synecdoche" has it. If I had to sum up such a mind-boggling film in 3 words, those are the words I'd choose.The Blu-Ray:On first glance, this is not a terribly impressive video transfer. It seems kind of dark and muddy and doesn't ooze detail. But over its two hours, it grew on me. It was never overblown color-wise, it always had a very "real" look to it, and I started to notice more detail in things like cloth and facial wrinkles (especially the detailed make-up) that were pleasing to the eye. So let us call it an average Blu-Ray presentation. Better than a DVD is capable of, sure, but not a barn-burning HD extravaganza.The sound design is good, as mentioned above in the complex atmospherics of both music and odd bleeps and bloops int he background.Extras include a 30-minute interview with Kaufman, a 15-minute piece with Hoffman, and a short but informative making-of piece. All are better than the average fluff one might see on a home video, the sort of bland pleasantries in which actors gush about how much they love each other. They are not overwhelming in terms of extra material, but they do add a pleasant layer of information to appreciating the film.I guess that's how I'd summarize the Blu-Ray presentation: not overwhelming, but good enough to let the film breathe and become an organic thing in the mind of the viewer.For these reasons, given the quality of the material and the adequate nature of the presentation, I think this Blu-Ray earns its five stars. It is not for everyone, but for the people who really "get it," it's a must-own.
summary: A Fever Dream About Life that deserves a chance on home video

reviewText: I've finally seen Charlie Kaufman's Synecdoche, New York, and jeezus. I thought his Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind was trippy. How this film didn't sweep the Oscars I don't understand. Wait, yes I do. It's relentlessly bleak--in that Woody Allen 'obsessed-with-death' way--but it's also belly crunch hilarious. Again, like in Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, he stretches and reshapes time (and space, to a degree) until you just have to let go, and yet, a firm narrative structure is always present, never abandoned. It's an amazing feat of screenplay-ism.The film is remarkably cast. Philip Seymour Hoffman is, well, he's one of the best actors working today and he is perfect for the role of representing, on film, the introverted, insecure because he's seen the abyss genius of Charlie Kaufman. His performance is better, ten times better, and funnier, than anything he's done before. Imagine that! Catherine Keener? Has any one ever had a bad word to say about her? If a fifth wall existed, this film would shatter it.Casual movie-goers will find Synecdoche, New York difficult, dark, pretentious and hopeless, but if you like film, if you like writing, if you like artistic commitment, if you like mind-bending hilarity, don't miss it.

reviewText: If clinical depression were to manifest itself then direct and star in its own biopic, the result would be nowhere near as depressing as this movie.  Don't get me wrong - it's certainly genius, of a type anyway.  Kaufman is the most original voice in cinema.  But this is just too bogged down in itself (intentionally) for humans to get anything out of.  Like the play it embodies, it truly could have gone on forever, each ticking second being one more bullet of despair to the brain.  I only held out to the end on the unreasonable hope that Kaufman, obviously a man with a keen sense of humor, would give me one candle moment to light the tarry abyss of his uncompromised vision.  No such grace was to be found.Instead we are treated to images of every bodily discharge in some state of disease or disarray, which might be okay if it ever led to anything.  But that's one of the problems - nothing leads anywhere.  Threads are created, explored, abandoned with no reason or measure.  I can only assume that it is all an intentional device to create the messiness-of-real-life feeling Kaufman wants to inflict.  However, we don't need to be told this, or have it played out for us - we're not that dim-witted Kaufman.All the actors do an excellent job, especially PSH who manages to imbue his character with no redeemable likability.  Such is the nature of the film as a whole - I give it 2 stars just for artistry, which manages to peek through the green poop of nihilism Kaufman seeks to fling into our souls. There were beautiful people all around him, supportive and caring, but he was ambivelent to it all. reviewText: Let me put this review in perspective.  I love Charlie Kaufman.  "Adaptation" and "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" are two of my favorite movies of all time.  I also have a history of loving bizarre movies, even if I don't understand everything that's going on.  "Brazil," "Mulholland  Drive," and "Primer" come to mind.So the problem isn't that "Synecdoche, New York" is "too weird" for me.  The problem is that, while those other films used their weirdness to enhance their stories or as pure mind-bending entertainment, the weirdness of this film just felt tedious and self-indulgent.  It trampled on my brain rather than engaging it.  The premise is intriguing (building a replica of a replica of a replica of reality), and the beginning of the film is quirky and funny, but the story just gets more and more complicated and emotionally detached, to the point that I couldn't wait for it to end.  It reminds me of what Quentin Tarantino did with "Death Proof," and P.T. Anderson did with "There Will Be Blood," and M. Night Shyamalan did with "The Happening."  You get to a point where you're popular enough to do whatever you want, and then you turn out a boring, self-indulgent mess.Bottom line: The film bored and confused me more than it entertained, but if you're a Charlie Kaufman fan or a fan of bizarre, challenging, and philosophical movies, you might want to give it a chance.  Apparently, many others have had the exact opposite experience as me, so you may find this more mentally stimulating than I did.Richard Yee, author of Deliveries: A Collection

reviewText: I don't even know how to start reviewing SYNECDOCHE, NEW YORK, the new film from writer (ETERNAL SUNSHINE, ADAPTATION) and first-time director Charles Kaufman.  I've been looking for a way in to this review since seeing the film two evenings ago.Here's the best I can come up with:  what WAITING FOR GODOT is to Theatre-Of-The-Absurd, SYNECDOCHE, NEW YORK is to Film-of-the-Absurd.  Both projects are brilliant, yet also maddeningly difficult to fathom at times.  GODOT, set on a stage decorated with just one bare tree, dared to explore the very condition of living in a world without meaning.  SYNECDOCHE uses all the tricks available to filmmakers to explore many of the same questions.  Or perhaps it's just one big question.GODOT is an all-time classic.  It is both the epitome and the definition of absurdist theatre.  Books have been written about it, and it is still stage with great regularity all over the world, by theatre companies eager to plumb new meaning (or any meaning) from it.  SYNECDOCHE will probably not generate such devotion or ruminations.  But to view this film is be immersed in the same feelings as a good production of GODOT will get you:  to laugh, to feel great sadness, to be confused as hell and to also feel that true understanding of it is tantalizing close, and yet always out of reach.(I'll admit right here that others will see this film and merely be extremely irritated by it, or think of it as a clever but somewhat boring mindgame.  These are also quite valid reactions.)The film begins on a seemingly typical day in the life of Caden (Phillip Seymour Hoffman) a theatre director in a smallish town in upstate New York (Synecdoche...and don't ask me why Kaufman didn't spell it Schenectady).  He's near the opening of his production of DEATH OF A SALESMAN, and he seems as miserable doing what he does as Willy Loman is with his life.  His clock radio comes on, and we hear that it is September 1.  When Caden arrives in the kitchen for breakfast, the TV tells us it is Halloween, and moments later, a story indicating the date as November 2 is on the radio.  So we get the idea, if we're paying attention, that Caden's days are all strikingly similar to each other and that if you see one morning, you're seeing them all.  Time is zooming by him.  To  him, he might experience a week, but in fact a year goes by.Anyway, Caden is married to Catherine Keener, a visual artist who paints very detailed and VERY tiny miniatures.  Some of the funniest moments in film this year revolve around these miniatures...but it's a dry wit.  (For example, here pictures are about 1" square.  She's sending some to a gallery in Berlin, and for each painting, she has constructed a tiny little shipping crate, complete with excelsior.)  Keener is also practically seething with loathing for Caden, because she feels he has long since given up searching for truth in his art.  They have a young daughter, Olive.Eventually, Caden's wife and child go to Berlin for a gallery opening, leaving Caden behind.  And they never return.  It is in these events that we begin to see how disconnected from life Caden is.  He still believes his daughter is a young girl...but she ages into a young adult.  Caden himself is visibly aging before our eyes...yet he doesn't seem aware of it.  He's afflicted by mysterious ailments, which to him seem to come virtually all at once...yet in reality, they are illnesses that might come one at a time over a many decade span.  The illnesses of aging.During his life, Caden is surrounded by many women.  Michelle Williams plays an actress who is enamored of  Caden, or at least his ability to get her cast.  Jennifer Jason Leigh plays Keener's best friend, who may also be leading his daughter Olive astray.  Hope Davis is his psychiatrist, who doesn't seem to be on his side at all. But most important is Hazel (Samantha Morton), his box office manager and the one woman who actually seems to cherish Caden...not that he can see it.As if this weren't confusing enough, early in the movie, Caden is awarded a grant to produce a giant, meaningful, truthful and important piece...anything he wants to do.  He rents perhaps the largest warehouse in the world and plans to stage "the truth."  He begins to construct a set that basically is to consist of every setting in his own life, and begins to cast actors who will play everyone he's ever known.  Yet he can never bring this piece to completion because while he attempts to stage his life, he continues to have a life, which results in needing to add more and more and more to the play.  Years and years and years go by.In two hours, we get to see all of Caden's adult life from the age of roughly 35.  He appears to experience it in just months.  Is Kaufman saying that Caden (and therefore US) are so busy trying to control, plan or understand our lives that it simply zooms by and we miss it?  Yes, that is part of it.  He's also reminding us that we are each the "stars" of our own lives...and that the supporting players in our lives are the "stars" of their own lives and that we might be more or less of supporting players in their lives than they are in ours.But in the end, it seems that Kaufman is trying to make us feel what it is like to live, to age, to come to grips with all our disappointments and to finally get down to a basic understanding of ourselves.  How everything is ultimately stripped away and we are left with nothing but our most basic needs.  And how if we're lucky, those needs MIGHT be met before we die.  But perhaps I'm wrong.  That's my impression, but I'll be every viewer takes away something different.The movie has many, many funny and ridiculous moments.  I found myself laughing out loud many times.  But the overall feeling is of a sadness so deep, it can only be a sadness of the soul.  It isn't a pleasant feeling, particularly as some of the moments may strike a chord...but it feels accurate.The film is beautifully made.  Kaufman has used CGI to craft a stage setting for Caden's "masterpiece" that is breathtaking in scale.  The makeup in the movie is wonderful as well...some of the most subtle aging work I've seen.Everyone is very good.  Keener is always an intelligent presence who pops off the screen, this time with barely concealed anger.  Davis and Williams are quite good.  Later, Emily Watson and Dianne Wiest make appearances, and they are also very welcome.  But I've got to give special notice to  3 performers.  Tom Noonan plays the man who is cast to play Caden in the play Caden produces.  Noonan is an amazing screen presence, and while for a change he isn't playing a killer (MANHUNTER, THE PLEDGE), he manages to be both sympathetic yet a little scary.  Samantha Morton deserves Oscar consideration for her glowing performance.  And Hoffman once again knocks it out of the park (big surprise!).  It's the kind of role we think he can do in his sleep...but he finds variations and tones that force him to dig deeper than we've seen.I'm going to stop here, because while I've told you a lot, I've only skimmed the surface.  SYNECDOCHE, NEW YORK is not going to be my favorite film of all time...but you can bet I'll return to it again and again, if only in the hopes of solving its beautiful and frustrating puzzle.
summary: A beautiful, funny, sad and OH SO FRUSTRATING masterpiece

reviewText: What happens when a hypochondriac really gets sick?  What happens when a self-absorbed small-town theatre director gets the chance, via a MacArthur "Genius grant", to stage a really big production?  What happens when an acclaimed script writer finally acquires enough clout to write and direct his own movie?Charlie Kaufman's screenplays have often mined the funhouse mirror of Hollywood imitating real life and vice versa -- John Malkovich playing John Malkovich, Nicolas Cage playing a writer named Charlie Kaufman, Jim Carrey falling in love over and over.  Synecdoche NY takes this narcissistic self-absorption to new heights (or depths according to your view).  It's a play-within-a-play set in a city-within-a-city, in which the characters hire actors to recite the things they just said, and sometimes even take over their lives for them -- Kaufman's ambitious directoral debut is every bit as self-referential as you'd expect.  It's a vertiginous, maddeningly inward-spiraling cinematic dream where the best coping mechanism is to simply release your hold on meaning and narrative and allow yourself to be sucked into Charlie's whirlpool.This is the darkest, least funny, and overall most downbeat of Charlie's films so far, which either will appeal to true Kaufman fans or will make them question their devotion. It's a film that benefits from a few repeated viewings, not so much because of its density but to appreciate the multiple interpretations possible.
